results.title: Dalziel and Scullion [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “TheEYE”.
Part of a series of interview-based profiles of contemporary visual artists in Britain. Artists Matthew Dalziel and Louise Scullion have worked together since 1993, based in the remote north east of Scotland. Using photography, video, sculpture, sound and installation, they have created a collection of work that is recognised for its distinctive vision and sensitivity to its context and the environment. The point at which nature and culture intersect is a continuing theme throughout their work. Well known for their site-specific works, which include important public commissions, their art reflects on the primary themes of landscape, evolution, religion and time, and represents a rediscovery of landscape as a means of reflecting on fundamental ideas about the world we live in today. In this profile, Dalziel and Scullion discuss their continuing fascination with timescales and how their work attempts to reflect on the vast gap that exists between the limits of human history and the incomprehensible span of geological processes and creation.

results.title: Anish Kapoor [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “TheEYE”.
Part of a series of interview-based profiles of contemporary visual artists in Britain. This profile of sculptor Anish Kapoor focuses on his extraordinary sculpture ‘Marsyas’ completed in October 2002. Installed in the Turbine Hall at Tate Modern, London, ‘Marsyas’ is a challenging and overwhelming artwork, a vast red PVC membrane stretched between three massive steel rings. This film follows the making of the work, from the earliest maquettes to the complex installation at Tate. Kapoor comments on each stage of the process, and on the ideas and concerns of his art. Also illustrated are a range of his other sculptures including two recent large-scale works: ‘Sky Mirror’ and ‘Taratantara’.

results.title: Gilbert and George [Widescreen] (D)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “TheEYE”.
Part of a series of interview-based profiles of contemporary visual artists in Britain. Gilbert Prousch met George Passmore at St Martin’s School of Art in 1967. Since then they have famously lived and worked together as Gilbert & George, creating an extraordinary body of provocative artworks. They have exhibited themselves as “Living Sculptures”, documented the banality of their daily lives in London’s East End, and, since the late 1970s, produced vibrant, challenging photographic collages. This profile of Gilbert & George features a characteristically deadpan performance of themselves. Sex, money, race and religion, they explain, are four themes at the heart of their art. Their interview is complemented by images of many of their works, including the remarkable Dirty Words Pictures made in 1977, together with important collages of the 1980s and 1990s. Please note: this video contains explicit images and adult language featured in artworks by Gilbert & George.

results.title: Little white lies
results.brief_description: Coming out is hard to do - but is procrastinating any easier? Reb finds that when you’ve got a secret and they’ve got your number, a little white lie can sometimes do wonders - but not always. Cast features Joy Smithers and Sylvia Mircevsky.

results.title: Zoo baby animals
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Opportunity for children to look behind the scenes at the zoo - to see activities in the kitchen and hospital; how baby animals are fed and cared for by their keepers. Shows many animals in attractive outdoor settings and in “children’s zoo” sections in the famous Lincoln Park and Brookfield Zoos of Chicago. Baby animals featured in the film are the lion, tiger, gorilla, bear, elephant, harbor seal, kudu, llama, Barbary sheep, tapir and baboon.

results.title: Zoo
results.creator_credit: Gerry Hudson, David Hughes, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: This film was made at the Melbourne Zoo and, without commentary, shows the activities - particularly eating - of birds in the air and animals on land and in water. There are some interesting close-ups of parts of animals, eg. the texture of the skin of a hippo and the back of an eagle.

results.title: Zoo
results.creator_credit: Gerry Hudson, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: This film explores a wide variety of animals on display at the Melbourne Zoo. All the major different animal groups are represented and each animal is shown in a natural environment. Gives a close look to animals we would not normally see at close range.

results.title: The Traditional world of Islam: nomad and city
results.brief_description: The nomads and the city dwellers - these are the two roles of Islamic civilization, and it is the tension existing between the two which has given to it an inner energy and capacity for self-renewal.
results.title_for_label: The Traditional world of Islam: nomad and city

results.title: The Traditional world of Islam: knowledge of the world
results.brief_description: The ideals of the Islamic religion are knowledge and certainty, the words “Seek knowledge from the cradle to the grave” being a famous teaching of Mohammed.
